mn87:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn87:2.1: Now at that time a certain householder’s dear and beloved only child passed away.
mn87:2.2: After their death he didn’t feel like working or eating.
mn87:2.3: He would go to the cemetery and wail,
mn87:2.4: “Where are you, my only child? Where are you, my only child?”
mn87:3.1: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
mn87:3.2: “Householder, you look like someone who’s not in their right mind; your faculties have deteriorated.”
mn87:3.3: “And how, sir, could my faculties not have deteriorated?
mn87:3.4: For my dear and beloved only child has passed away.
mn87:3.5: Since their death I haven’t felt like working or eating.
mn87:3.6: I go to the cemetery and wail:
mn87:3.7: ‘Where are you, my only child? Where are you, my only child?’”
mn87:3.8: “That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!
mn87:3.9: For our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”
mn87:3.10: “Sir, who on earth could ever think such a thing!
mn87:3.12: For our loved ones are a source of joy and happiness.”
mn87:3.13: Disagreeing with the Buddha’s statement, rejecting it, he got up from his seat and left.
mn87:4.1: Now at that time several gamblers were playing dice not far from the Buddha.
mn87:4.2: That householder approached them and told them what had happened.
mn87:4.17: “That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!
mn87:4.18: For our loved ones are a source of joy and happiness.”
mn87:4.19: Thinking, “The gamblers and I are in agreement,” the householder left.
mn87:5.1: Eventually that topic of discussion reached the royal compound.
mn87:5.2: Then King Pasenadi addressed Queen Mallikā,
mn87:5.4: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’”
mn87:5.5: “If that’s what the Buddha said, great king, then that’s how it is.”
mn87:5.6: “No matter what the ascetic Gotama says, Mallikā agrees with him:
mn87:5.7: ‘If that’s what the Buddha said, great king, then that’s how it is.’
mn87:5.8: You’re just like a student who agrees with everything their teacher says.
mn87:5.12: Go away, Mallikā, get out of here!”
mn87:6.1: Then Queen Mallikā addressed the brahmin Nāḷijaṅgha,
mn87:6.2: “Please, brahmin, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
mn87:6.5: ‘Sir, did the Buddha make this statement:
mn87:6.6: “Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress”?’
mn87:6.7: Remember well how the Buddha answers and tell it to me.
mn87:6.8: For Realized Ones say nothing that is not so.”
mn87:6.9: “Yes, ma’am,” he replied. He went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
mn87:6.10: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
mn87:6.11: “Master Gotama, Queen Mallikā bows with her head to your feet. She asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
mn87:6.14: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’”

mn87:8.1: And here’s a way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
mn87:8.2: Once upon a time right here in Sāvatthī a certain woman’s mother passed away.
mn87:8.3: And because of that she went mad and lost her mind. She went from street to street and from square to square saying,
mn87:8.4: ‘Has anyone seen my mother? Has anyone seen my mother?’

mn87:22.1: Once upon a time right here in Sāvatthī a certain woman went to live with her relative’s family.
mn87:22.2: But her relatives wanted to divorce her from her husband and give her to another,
mn87:22.4: So she told her husband about this.
mn87:22.7: But he cut her in two and disemboweled himself, thinking,
mn87:22.9: That’s another way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”
mn87:23.1: Then Nāḷijaṅgha the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat, went to Queen Mallikā, and told her of all they had discussed. Then Queen Mallikā approached King Pasenadi and said to him,
mn87:24.5: If she were to decay and perish, would sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise in you?”

mn87:24.8: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’
